Body:
I have a database of one million strings which I want to rank against one another so that I can tell which contain meaningful English words / sentences.

These strings contain no spaces or punctuation. Some contain real English words:

THISISASENTENCETHATCONTAINSENGLISHWORDS

Some are a jumble of random letters:

IHWEIONMSACOMDSCKNENCIJNCDSKMCDJCSJDNJL

Currently I use an updated Mayzner letter frequency list, and I count for occurrences of most common tri/bigrams in the above strings.

["th","he","in","er","an"], // Mayzner most common 2grams
["the","and","ing","ion","tio"] // Mayzner most common 3grams

The first string contains more occurrences of these ngrams, so would rank above the second string in terms of its Englishness.

The above method works OK but I want to improve it.

Here are some of the improvements I've looked into:

  • Vowel to consonant ratio.
  • Vowel and consonant positions within string.
  • Letter positions / relation to one another. e.g. The bigrams: JQ, QG, QK, QY, QZ, WQ, and WZ, should never occur in the English language.
  • Dictionary search (i.e. match most commonly used words from an English dictionary)
  • E,T,A,O,I,N being the most occurring letters, in this order.

What are the most important factors for determining whether a string contains English words? Maybe it would be a combination of these?
Title: Common English bigrams / trigrams - recognising that a jumble of letters contain only valid English words
